p.s: In order to present his critical view on the steady decline of foreign language, Worne makes use of a variety of communicative strategies as well as a clear structure and emotive use of language.
First of all Worne makes use of an enumeration and climax in the beginning can't, won't, don't(l. 1).
With this technique he makes sure that the sentence staystays in the readersreader's mind.
Moreover he points out how dramatic the situation, that fewer people speak foreign languages, is from his point of view.
With this technique he wants to catch the readersreader's attention right in the beginning and he wants to make his personal view on the issue clear.
Another communicative strategiestrategy is in line six: languages are now on the menu in more primary schools(ll. 6-7).
With this metaphor Worne wants to say that more primary schools offer to learn a foreign langugelanguage.
Furthermore he creatscreates an image in the readersreader's mind and makemakes his text more visual and interesting.
To sound more trustworthy and knowledgebalknowledgeable the author names facts More than 10,000 fewer language A level exams [...] than at the end of the 1990s(ll. 9-10).
To add, the author makes use of another enumeration: trade, prosperity, cultural exports, diplomacy and nattionalnational security(ll. 17-18).
With this enumeration Worne points out the importance of languages for the UK.
The enumeration streessesstresses and underlineunderlines the importance of the skill to speak different languages clear is aananaphora in lines 16-17 Languages [...] languages.
Both sentences explain the use of languages in the daily life and in the work life.
Moreover Worne also uses a statistic to proof his points and convince the reader even more The most recent CBI / Pearson Education and Skills Survey showed(ll. 19-20).
The statistic proofsproves that language is important for the business in the UK.
Another strategiestrategy to consider is the use of an exampelexamplea lawyer with Chinese language skills is more demand than a pure lawyer or a pure linguist(ll. 28-29).
With this example he makes his point more visual and als contrastalso contrasts a person with language skills with one who has not those skills.
With the contrast his argument seems to be stronger.
Another contrast is in ll. 6-8.

In this paragraph the author first mentions the progress of languages in primary schools and then the stillstand in secondary schools as well as in A-levelsA-Levels with this technique the progress he mentioned first does not seem to be such a good thing anymore because the stillstand gets in the foreground.
In line 32 the author directly adresses the reader So parents, of the UK(l. 32).
Because of the direct adress, the reader gets involved and starts to feel personallpersonally attached.
With the addition I'm one Worne makes clear that he is on the same wave lengthwavelength as the reader.

Furthermore Worne uses inclusive language we as parents(l. 33) to make the reader feel even more involved and to make them start thinking about what they can do to help more children to learn different languages.
In the fifth paragraph (ll. 12-15) Worne refuterefutes the argument not to worry(l. 12) not by giving antithesis they don't(l. 13), but you may crash or choke(ll. 14).
To make his point clear, to make his article interesting and to reach a lot of people Worne makes use of a mixture between formal and informal language.

On the one hand he uses informal terms such as re-commissioning our collective brains(l. 5) acobbleres(l. 15) but on the other handshand he also uses formal terms such as is vital for the UK's future prosperity and global standing(l. 16).

Moreover Worne also makes use of emotional language like sadly(l. 4), Cobblers(l. 15)... With his emotional tone he shows the reader how important the topic is for him and that he is personal attached.

All in all one can say that the author stresses his critical view on the steady decline of foreign language speakerspeakers with his use of communicative strategysstrategies and his emotional use of language.
